subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: ... Right. That s how I parsed the dictionary. Actually, whenever I came upon AA, I transliterated this as y||o, so that when I see these words tranliterated,
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:

>
> If you open the actual CMU text file and look up the lexical set names
> PALM (which uses symbol AA), LOT (AA), THOUGHT(AO) and CLOTH (AO) the
> CMU merger is quite clear

Right. That's how I parsed the dictionary. Actually, whenever I came
upon AA, I transliterated this as y||o, so that when I see these words
tranliterated, I can decide which letter is more suitable. (fy||oTar =>
fyTar.)


>
> The CMU is not RP of course but some idealized American and aside from
> merging away #34, it also has no #20Whiteweat/Why

Yes, which I don't know if that represents a problem or not. I don't
pronounce the "h," but spelling that way may look odd to others.

>
> Another intractable problem that can *look* like a spelling mistake is
> the fault of English itself: the same word is pronounced differently
> based on it's grammatical use. In particular the word "use" is
> pronounced differently when it is a noun (s ending) and when it is a
> verb (z ending). The CMU dictionary provides both entries (you can see
> them in the CMU text file with a parenthesis (2) after the second).
> But this is useless because figuring out the part of speech of
> words from a live feed using python is a tad ambitious.
>

Another example is wind, which can mean what blows or what you do to an
old fashioned clock. I have this as wind|wFnd in my private dictionary.
I have to correct the word after a transliteration, which I can't do for
the news. So we will have to tolerate some mistakes in the news, at
least for now.

Paul
